title: 111_hr3635
content: The "Disaster Relief and Recovery Development Act of 2009" requires a study on alert systems' ability to provide disaster information to individuals with limited English proficiency. A report with recommendations for additional resources must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 3 of the Act requires the President to review and streamline regulations and policies related to Federal disaster assistance within one year of enactment. A report on changes made must be submitted to Congress within 18 months. SEC. 4 pertains to the issuance of regulations regarding eligible costs. SEC. 4 of the Act mandates the President to issue regulations within six months to expedite cost estimation procedures for recovery projects. SEC. 5 increases the use of financial assistance for disseminating information on mitigation technologies. SEC. 6 outlines recovery responsibilities. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include functions of the Federal Coordinating Officer, such as making an initial appraisal of recovery assistance needed and coordinating with State officials on recovery plans. Additionally, amendments are made to Emergency Support, Response, and Recovery Teams. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include functions of the Federal Coordinating Officer, such as making an initial appraisal of recovery assistance needed and coordinating with State officials on recovery plans. Amendments are made to Emergency Recovery Teams, including the establishment of national and regional teams to meet incident management responsibilities. The Administrator ensures target capability levels for Federal emergency recovery teams are established as per guidelines. Teams must have adequate personnel to achieve these levels and work with State and local officials. Readiness is evaluated regularly and reported on by the Administrator. The Administrator evaluates team readiness regularly and reports levels as required by the Post-Katrina Emergency Management Reform Act of 2006. SEC. 327. FEDERAL INTERAGENCY DISASTER RECOVERY TASK FORCE is added to the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The President shall establish a Federal interagency disaster recovery task force to identify and report on Federal programs for disaster recovery. The task force, chaired by the Administrator of FEMA, will ensure communication between relevant Federal departments and agencies. The President will establish a Federal interagency disaster recovery task force to identify and report on Federal programs for disaster recovery. The task force, chaired by the Administrator of FEMA, will ensure communication between relevant Federal departments and agencies. Each department and agency determined by the President will administer programs for recovery after a disaster or emergency, with the task force meeting at least four times a year. SEC. 8 amends Section 406(a) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act by reducing the amount from $20,000,000 to $5,000,000 and requires the President to provide contribution status reports every 180 days. SEC. 9 establishes a special rule for certain major disasters. Section 406 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to allow for the consolidation of funds in the case of extensive damage from a major disaster. This amendment permits a State, local government, or private nonprofit facility to receive a lump sum payment to repair, restore, reconstruct, or replace multiple public facilities. The decision to repair or replace these facilities is left to the discretion of the State, local government, or nonprofit facility after assessing the need post-disaster. The Federal share for a public facility after a major disaster shall be 100 percent of the cost of repairing, restoring, reconstructing, or replacing the facilities.
